element_texts.text: Completed

Pala. Cal.
Aug. 17. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here all right
am located in a very lonesome
place one mile from the Agency
with a Mexican family.
After Supper I walked to the
Agency, it was dark could not
see much but called at the
Indian traders store and he told
me I could board with an old
Indian woman in the Agency
so if it is all right I will go
there tomorrow as then I will be
with more people, dont think
I will have any trouble to get
the Indians to sit for me
I stopped at noon at
the Ramona Ranch on the way
stopped at the San Luis Rey
Mission a fine place there
are several Monks there.
The Ramona Ranch is a beautiful
Completed

place with hills and mountains
all around it, it comprises 3000
acres and is for sale for $75,000
There is no doubt Ramona lived
there The livery man at Ocean side
whom I rented a team of owns
the ranch his Grandfather bought
it in 1850 and lived and died
there the livery man was raised
there, he told me when he was
a boy he remembers of Helen Jackson
being there and writing the book
said he used him in one of the 
characters. No one lives there now
but two old men and the place 
is not kept up going to decay
The house is very large has
20 rooms built in a square
with a court some 70 feet
square inside which is beautiful
a fountain is in the center
and flowers the rooms and
furniture are the same as of old
I ate Dinner in the old dining
Completed

(3) room I took several photos
of the place, one funny thing
the old men living there have
never read the book "Ramona"
said they had heard of the book.
There are several old fire places
in the house fine old courts
it is a magnificent ranch and 
home.
They had a sign painted up part
of it was obliterated it said
Visitors were tolerated but
never welcome so I thought
I would receive a cold greeting
but to my surprise I was
welcome and remained as long
as I wished to.
They have an old fashioned
bathing place out doors built
of clay where they bathed out 
doors.
This is a beautiful country
very mountainous. The Mission
Completed

Indians seem to be well fixed
farm a good deal They have
fine land. I saw some Indians
in the store this eve" and I
like their looks.
The house I am in now is
a winery and they have a 
farm also.
It seems very quiet to me after
so much noise in Los Angeles.
I called on Mr Lummis but
once.
The Ramona house has fine
big red tiles for a roof.
If you wish I will send you
a set of the photo's I took there.
There is an old Mission at
the Agency here call Pala
Mission.
Love to you and all
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge
Completed

Pala. Calif.
Aug. 19. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am nicely located
here have rented a house of
an Indian here and have it
all to my self, all the furniture
there was in the house was
a cook stove and three broken
chairs so I have rented
a cot bed clothes, etc at the
store and get my meals
at a Restaurant kept by a
big fat jolly Indian woman,
at present I am the only boarder
she whistles all the time she is
cooking, The food is very plain
which suits me.
These Indians were moved here
from Warners Ranch that is
part of them. they have a beautiful
country here surrounded with
mountains. They raise oranges
Completed

Olives Grapes etc The houses they
live in were built in New York state
a portable house, comfortable good
ventilation but not durable they
have some 80 of them and water
at each house.
An old Mission called Pala
Mission is here restored some
what, the Indian trader occupies
one end of it as a store and
dwelling place.
These Indians are a little hard
to get to pose for me but
I am getting them have to be
very patient with them let them
have their own way, They will any
have it way, have finished two red
drawings so far, those I have
finished are the San Louis Rey
Indians there are two other
tribes here. the men as a rule
wear a mustache and some have
short hair growing on their chin
resembling whiskers.
I will not be able to do much
work next week as the Indians
Completed

are to give a grand Fiesta they
are making big preparations for it
it is to be held here they are to
have a feast horse racing games
dances etc for four days.
After that is over I will get
the old men to sit for me. 
They are superstitious but I can
overcome that.
There is a mine a mile from
here called a Gem mine owned
and operated by Tiffany in New York
I saw the gems they get from it
it resembles a diamond very brilliant
but purplish in color they are very
expensive.
I probably will remain here a 
month. I am naming the drawings
I am making by the tribes or
Mission these Indians belonged to,
They all are commonly called the
Mission Indians but there are
several distinct tribes they belonged
to.
These Indians seem to be good
Completed

workers and very friendly.
The weather here is comfortable
not very warm, the evenings are
quite cool. we are some 24
miles from the Ocean.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. The Los Angeles Examiner
to to have quite an article 
about my work.
Completed

Pala. Calif.
Aug 20. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting along
fine here am getting all
the subjects I want.
I made a portrait of one
of the principal Warner
Ranch Indians he said
he would sit for more
portraits.
I expect the Fiesta here
this week will be very
interesting as the Indians
are to give their old time
dances games, etc.
I am reading the book
Ramona here, several
old men living here
Completed

told me they knew Helen
Jackson personally that she
was here at Pala several
times getting characters for 
her story.
The old Indian woman
where I get my meals
name is Ramona, they
tell me she claims to be
Ramona in the story.
I am afraid I will
not be able to do much
work during the Fiesta
as it is a regular 4th of
July here then.
These Indians seem to
be happy and well
satisfied with their lot
They raise good crops
lots of vegetables water
Completed

melons etc
About all of them are
Catholics very devout
The Priest hold services
in the old Pala Mission
which has been restored
by the Landmarks Club
and looks fine, they
are doing good work
in restoring these old
Missions.
I probably will remain
here for several weeks as
there seem to be several 
tribes of the Mission
Indians here.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pala. California.
Aug. 26. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting along fine here
have all the models I can take
care of have them waiting in turn.
The Fiesta is on now I sent you
a bill of it. It is very interesting
and lots of fun I thought it
would interfere with my work but
I get to work early in the
morning and am all through at
Noon so have the afternoons to
do as I please in The Fiesta is
a credit to the Indians the
management and all of course
There are lots of Mexicans here
and they have different gambling
devices quite harmful. The
Indian women have several
restaurants at the Fiesta 25
cts a meal pretty good meal
healthy food it agrees with me
Some Indians are here near by
and give queer dances every
night by a big camp fire.

Indian boys are here from
Completed

other towns and they have a
match game of ball. They have a
purse up and besides, the ball
players bet and it is a good
game devoid from any loud
talking or wrangling when the
Indian umpire makes a decision
that settles it not a single
dispute no matter what it is.
They have erected a dancing 
platform in the center of the court
and dance every night during
the Fiesta every thing goes on
as smoothly no fights or
loud talking just happy and
laughing the old woman
Ramona has a restaurant at
the Fiesta so I eat with 
her there.
There are four tribes of Indians
here San Luis Rey, Pala
San Felippo and Warners Ranch.
I always thought that the
reason the Warner Ranch
Completed

Indians were removed was
on account of the land, did not
have enough to eat and some
of them starving but I have
talked with several of the Warner
Ranch Indians and all of them
tell me the land was all right
only they did not own it and
the man who owned it wanted
too much for it they say they
had plenty to eat and some
of them were better off than
here as there on the Warner 
Ranch they have hot springs
and lots of visitors come there
for the baths and the Indians
sold things to them did their
washing etc.
They surely have a beautiful
country here as fine a place as
I ever saw fertile land fine
water and a beautiful climate
can raise most any thing
and they all look well.
Completed

I had some trouble with an
old San Felippo Indian woman,
after sitting a half hour she wanted
to quit I remonstrated with her
so she sat another half hour and
did quit, she walked out but
I followed her she would not
return said she was tired but
I got some one to translate for me
and I talked to her pretty plain and
she returned but in a little
while got up and went home
so I went to one of the head
Indians here who has influence
with these Indians and gave him
a dollar and told him I wanted
him to talk to these Indians for 
me told him about the old
woman he went and saw her
and she came next day and
sat as long as I wanted her 
to, I got three good red drawings
of her and then her husband
came and made some of him.
These Indians make fine baskets
Completed

(5) a good many of them speak
English. I am afraid I will
have some trouble in getting the
young Indian girls to sit for me
I made drawings of two and
had them against their own wishes
take down their hair. they braid
their hair like a white girl and
I do not make portraits of any
of the girls with their hair worn
like a white girl, so the Indian
girls told me they would not
sit for me unless I would
let them braid their hair They said
they have always braided their hair
but I guess I will get them all
right the way I want them.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. Aug 28. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I just noticed this ending of a
letter to you, which I mailed the
other day. So send it now.
Completed

Pala. California
Sept. 2. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours just received
and glad to hear from you.
I should like to see your Automobiles
they must be a fine ones. I would
enjoy the trip to Chicago with you.
I am getting along fine here
Am afraid I will not be able
to send you any red drawings until
I reach the railroad as I do 
not care to trust them with
the stage that carries the mail,
here, he just has a two wheel cart
and I am afraid the package
would get lost.
These Indians are very thrifty
live in a fine place but most
of them I have talked with are
sorry they had to leave Warners
Ranch. Today I was talking 
with an Indian woman some
30 years old she speaks good
English I asked her to tell me
about Warners Ranch. She said
Completed

they were all born there, her Mother also
was born there she now is a woman
some 70 years old (she sat for me)
she said it was their home and
her Mother told her as long as she
can remember the land belonged
to these Indians but one day
a white man claimed it the Indians
went to law about it and last
she said it was fine land they
raised what they wanted, had
built them selves comfortable good
adobe houses and were contented
and happy hot springs are there
and she said lots of Americans
came there for the baths and the
Indians made money out of them
sold baskets etc. She said we
used to be so clean there as
every night all of us would take
a bath in the warm water.
Her Father said, well there is
no use complaining we are here
and will make the best of it.
Temeculah a Town 12 miles
from here on The Santa Fe R.R.
Completed

(3) years ago the Indians lived
there and built them selves homes
but the whites came in and drove
them out Helen Hunt Jackson
mentions it in her book "Ramona."
but these Indians surely have
fine home now fine fertile land
can irrigate a good share of it
and raise fine crops, as fine
water melons and musk melons
as I ever ate. If the Hopis
had as good a country as this
they would be overjoyed. when I
think of the country they live in
all sand and have so many
difficulties to overcome to even
raise scarcely enough to eat.
These Indians are now gathering
their corn and shelling it to sell
in the market they get $2.00 a sack,
in my leisure moments I help them
shell corn.
The Fiesta is over and the place
has resumed its quiet natural
Completed

pose, some whiskey was smuggled
in with bad results no shooting
or fights but quite a number
of drunks. The other day I was
walking down by the creek and
run across five drunken Indians
one was asleep on the ground
They called me over to them and
wanted me to make a portrait
of an old man who was among
them. I told them all right bring
him around tomorrow, his hand
was hurt I said why dont you
get a Doctor for his hand
they said he was a Doctor a
great Doctor that he had great
powers, that I could stand
off ten feet and he could drop
me to the ground with out touching
me. I did not dispute them,
but thought to my self he could
drop a horse or man by blowing
his breath at them 10 feet away.
I had a hard time to get away
Completed

from them. I have not seen
the old Doctor since.
There are virtually five tribes here
Pala, San Luis Rey, San Felippo,
Warner Ranch and Agua Calienta. but
the Warner Ranch and Agua Calienta are
about the same tribe. There are
several tribes of the Mission Indians
with in a radius of 75 miles
around here and I will go to them
all. They are nice people to be with
very friendly but resemble Mexicans
as many of them wear a mustache
and whiskers but strong types.
It is getting pretty warm here now
but not so but what I work
all right. have not lost a 
minute since arrived here.
There is a good Indian traders
store here every thing very
reasonable and they carry a
good stock such as Indians 
care for.
Completed

I probably will be here two or
three weeks more then will go to
the nearest place from here.
The Indian woman I board with is
improving on her meals. I am still
the only boarder.
These Indians have fine horses and
cattle well fed also a lot of
sheep and are in better condition
than most tribes I have been to.
School has commenced now and
several of the children have gone
away to school most of them to
Riverside some 60 miles from here
They have a good day school here
for the younger children.
I am getting drawings of the head
men here and I like them as well
as ever better than any have made.
All these Indians are devout
Catholics go to Church every 
Sunday in the old Pala Mission
a Priest or Father is here all the
time a nice man.
The Lands mark Club has done
Completed

(7) good work here the
Mission here was all in 
ruins the roof had caved
in, the walls were built 
up and a new roof
put on and the original 
tiles used it is a long
building and The Land
marks Club own it and
rent part of it to the
Indian trader and the
Father lives and has
his Church in the rest of
it. The old original tower 
is still standing with
the two original bells in
Completed

in it and the old grave
yard back of it.
There are several old
old Indian people here
some of them must be
over 100 and they are
big powerful built people
large bodies and look
so healthy and strong
These old people say
that the reason they are
so well and big and
strong is because the
way they were brought
up when children said
they lived close to Nature
ate natural food such 
as roots herbs and
Completed

(9)
wild fruit but now 
their children eat store
food canned goods etc
a good deal, do not 
eat as much herbs and
roots as they should as
it is too much work to
gather, the store is handier
but most of them eat
a mush made of acorns
I see such as difference
in their children they are
smaller have not the
statue their parents had
not so strongly and well
built and have more
Completed

aches and pains. I my
self am careful do not
eat any canned goods
at all, so the old
Indian woman has to
cook me common food
They make a chili out 
of raw tomatoes red or
green peppers and raw
onions and vinegar which
is fine so good for ones
stomach. they chop it
up fine.
I received a letter from
Mr Lummis he told me
to be sure and get
Pio Amago at La Joya
to sit for me I will
Completed

I will do so when I get 
there, not far from here.
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Pala. California.
Sept. 8. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I had a talk with
the Indian Agent here
who is a fine man
he understands The Indian.
He gave me the
names of the other
places where The Mission
Indians live, There are
eight more different
tribes of The Mission
Indians around here 
viz Pechanga,
Completed

Rincon, La jolla,
Mesa Grande, Volcan,
Inaja, Capitan Grande
and Campo. The 
Campo's are the ones
who are or were in
a bad condition had
to have help from out-
side. I will go to all
these places and will
start in a few days
I have a lot of good
drawings of the Indians
here the best types 
and among them the
head people.
There is a Yaqui Indian
here I made drawings
Completed

(3)
of him he is married to
a Mission Indian woman
and has a fine family
he is an industrious Indian
works hard he cleared
a lot of land here and
planted corn and
vegetables on it.
This afternoon another
gentleman and my
self went on the top
of one of the mountains
near by on our return
went to the Lithia
mine I believe the
only one in America
Completed

it is quite a mine
has a tunnel passing
through the mountain
the miner took us all
through it the rock
is sent East and there
made into Lithia tablets.
I am getting all the
Indians to sit for me
I can take care of had
a fine old subject to
day an old man he
is to come tomorrow.
I met an Indian woman
yesterday who said she
knows Ramona the 
character in the Ramona
story said she lives a
few miles from here
Completed

imitate the dead and
dance and march with
Them and then from the
images wh.  An old
Indian woman is hired to
scold any enemies who
are living of? the dead
she will call their names
out and give Them a
good scalding. They used
to have a fire dance
where They would dance 
in a fire barefooted and
put The fire out with
their feet and hands,
before going into The
fire They would rub
Them Selves all over with

             1104
Completed

she said she was well
acquainted with Helen
Hunt Jackson said she
was a little girl when
she was here and Helen
Jackson used to hear her
recite her lessons and
read for her. The Yaqui
Indian is her Father.
Years ago these Indians
use to have several
dances and ceremonies even
now once in so often
they have a ceremony where
they mourn for the dead
They make images to

                 9-8-05
Completed

(7)
some herb They gathered.
The weather is getting
cooler here now and
am glad of it, The evenings 
are fine, to sleep.
I am Told The land is
all allotted to These
Indians here but none
of Them as yet live on
Thise allotments They 
prefer living in a village,
to have all Their houses
near each other, The
Place? where They live
has two atreets like a
Town, the houses unclear

                           9-8-05
Completed

in regular rows and
each house numbered
and running water to 
each house, only the
houses are small and
not durable they
probably will last
five years longer,
some of the houses the
Indians have built on
to and some have a
tent back of the house
some have nice yards
with flowers planted and
a vegetable garden and
well taken care of, they
the Indians seem to be
clean judging from the
Completed

washing of clothes I see
them doing quite often,
They have water enough
to keep clean. and on a
whole they are in good
conditions and more
contented and happy.
There seems to be very little
if any sickness among 
them.
There are only about
20 Pala Indians living
they live about a
mile from here I will
get some of them to sit
for me.
Completed

They have lived in this
valley where this Pala
Mission is all their lives.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

Pala Calif.
Sept 19. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am painting 
some oil portraits
now for a change.
Am painting Indian
girls as They have 
long hair am
posing them in nice
positions, finished one
today which I think
one of the best Indian
portraits have painted
There is another tribe
of Indians called
"Cahuillo" Indians here,
There are but very few
Completed

of them here I will
get red drawings of them
I have a lot of red
drawings finished now
I expect to leave here
any way in two or
three weeks will go
to Pechango where
the Indians by that
name live it is some
six miles from here.
There is no Post Office
there or any store, the 
nearest town is some
six miles from there
called Temecula on
a branch of the Santa
Fe R.R. when I get
to Pechanga will
go to Temecula and
send the red drawings
Completed

to you I have a fine
lot but am going
to make some more
There are seven different
tribes here. Indians
who would not sit
for me at first want
to sit now. There is
one old man here one
of the principal Indians
who refuses to sit for
me but I am quite
sure to get him yet.
The Indian woman
who cooks for me
was not around
to night for Supper
so I had to go to the
store and eat crackers
sardines and cheese.
If she does not
show up tomorrow
Completed

I will have to find some 
Indian family to eat
with, one thing they have
healthy food such as
it is, but one has to
close their eyes to the
mode of cooking and
the way the food is
served to relish it, 
which I have learned
to do.
These Indians seem to
be industrious working
on their land they 
have raised quite a 
little hay and corn
and some have a good
many cattle.
Completed

The Indian Agent here
gives them all the work
he can such as
hauling freight etc and
some are teachers in
some of the day schools.
Quite a number of
the Indian girls go
to different towns
to work in Hotels and
private families
The Indian men also
work for other farmers
some of the old women
go away to pick
fruit etc so they 
get along very will
but they have not 
yet gotten over their
Completed

leaving Warners Ranch
there they say they had
such nice homes, large
comfortable houses built
of adobe which is the
very best kind of a house
for this climate cool
in Summer and warm
in Winter while these
portable houses are
hot in Summer and 
cold in Winter and
too small for them
They are to have another
Fiesta they tell me
on Oct 8 they will
not be to much expense
this time as the
shanties are all up
that they used at the 
last Fiesta.
Last week they had
Completed

a Fiesta some ten
miles from here but it
was managed by the
Mexicans and am told
there was a lot of
drinking going on.
In a letter I received
from my Father he
wrote that Lizzie
had not been very well
I hope she is well
ere this and enjoying
her usual good health
I am feeling first 
rate. I exercise a
good deal am out
doors all I can be
and careful of what
I eat. The Indian
Woman is a good cook
She cooks me Spanish
dishes which I like
Completed

I hope she has not
gone away She is a
big strapping woman
has a good sized
husband but she is too
much for him, much
stronger can handle
him easily and she
does sometimes he
has the reputation of
being a mean fellow.
but he is a good fellow
when he is with her,
he has learned by sad 
experience that he has to
be, she is a very sensible
good hard working
woman.
Completed

Quite a number of the
Indian girls are quite
friendly and very
talkative and tell
me lots about the
Indians and themselves.
Nearly all of them are
Catholics and go to
the Mission Church
here, a Priest lives in
the Church all the time,
a very nice man, he 
tends strictly to his
own affairs.
In olden times these
Indians used to cremate
their dead but they 
tell me since the 
Priests have come here
Completed

they bury their dead.
Well I must close
and go to bed.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge
Completed

Pala. California.
Sept. 25. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I will be leaving here in 
a few days for Pichango six
miles from here where the Temecula
Indians are a branch of the Mission
Indians. There is no Post Office
or store there but think I can get
a place to stop. if not will go on
to Temecula six miles from Pichango
The Indians go there to trade, but
it is more difficult to get the
Indians to sit where they go to a
town to trade as generally when
they are through trading, they want
to return home, but I will get
them however.
I will send you a lot of red
drawings soon by Express have a
nice lot, the best types of
The Pala, San Luis Reg San Felippo
Agua Caliente Yaqui and Warner Ranch
Indians here at Pala.
Completed

These Indian men have been cutting
their hair for a great many years
and have worn a mustache and
whiskers for many years, an old man
told me to day that he came here
by ox team from Texas nearly
40 years ago and they were the
same then as now.
When any of these Mission Indians
die his will is made beforehand
telling who he owes money to and
after his death if he has property
and money enough his debts are
all paid, if not his relatives and
friends pay his debts, it is an
old custom with them and a good
one as are many of their other
traits.
I keep hearing of different branches
of the Mission Indians was told 
of the Cahuilla Indians whose home
is some 30 miles from here, will go
there. There are two Cahuilla Indians
here they are noted Foot ball players
am told as good as any in
Completed

America.
I will find some very interesting
Indians up in the mountains I am 
told.
Senator Flint of California was in to
see me yesterday he was much
interested in the portraits especially
the red drawings he thought it a fine
idea getting these portraits and having
them preserved as they will be.
I enjoy the work and like the
life and feeling well and doing
just what I want to, so naturally
am very well contented.
I am working pretty hard but
not overworking.
I will write you soon as I get
settled in next place.
My address will be Temecula.
Riverside Co. California.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge
Completed

Pala. California.
Sept. 28. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am packed ready to
leave in the morning for
Pichanga. Calif.
I will send you tomorrow
by Express 38 red drawings
which I am sure you will be
pleased with.
You will notice that nearly
all the Indian men have a
mustache and whiskers
which they have worn for
a great many years as
long as any of the white
people around here can
remember.
In the same box, I am sending
you a lead pencil drawing
I made of the Yuma's mode
of cremating their dead.
Completed

Had to make it in a hurry for
fear the Yuma's would interrupt
me. I make you a present of the
lead pencil drawing.
You can send a check as
before to H. D. Crumbs Bank.
Harvard. Ill's.
These red drawings ought to
have a glass over them in a narrow
very plain wood frame, which
will protect them more and the
frame sealed on the back.
If you have an idea of doing
this I would advise you to go
to Mueller Bros Wabash Ave
as they would do the work very
reasonable and first class.
Excuse short letter.
Will write you soon, soon as
am settled.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. My address will be
Temecula. River Side Co.
California.
Completed

Temecula California.
(Pichanga) Sept. 29. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I arrived here at Pichanga
Today Then went on to Temecula
where Railroad is and Post Office
is and sent a box of pictures to you.
This is the dreariest and lonesomest
place ever was in, in my life.
There are a few families of the 
Temecula Indians here and are
scattered around among the hills
here living in wood shacks built
by them selves and some of them live
in old brush houses rudely constructed
I think they live on their own
allotments. I am the only white
man here and am living with
the Indian policeman in an old
shanty of a house of two rooms
one a bed room with two beds
in the room and such beds
Completed

I think he made them him self.
The other room is a general room
to store things in with a dirt
floor which I will have to use
as a Studio, the Kitchen is a brush
house. but I am glad to be as
comfortable as am.
They have a good Country here
except the drinking water which
they have to go some five miles
for in barrels. There is a fine
Spring some 4 miles up the
mountains which the Indians want
The Government to pipe down to
their homes. It ought to be done
as these Indians were bodily
moved from Temecula where there
is fine water and they came here
and have been here ever since.
I dont expect to have as easy a
time getting these Indians to sit
for me as at Pala as these
people are scattered around so
but I will get enough good 
types. I have the Indian policeman
Completed

(3) working for me, he seems to be
a nice obliging fellow. think he
will sit for me.
The Fiesta is going on here of 
the same character as the one at
Pala The same gambling games
etc and it will be hard for me
to get subjects until it is over
which will be in two or three
days. I have to walk to the
Fiesta about a mile for my
meals as the Policemans wife
has a restaurant there.
I wish you could see the paper 
on the wall in this bedroom
it looks as though they had
got several small rods of paper
from a store and posted all the 
different patterns on the wall some
upside down and sideways I dare
say he has nearly 80 different
patterns of wall paper posted on the
boards in this room, some places
newspaper and pictures cut out of
books pasted on the walls. If one
Completed

was sick, they would have enough
diversion to study the different patterns
The mail comes here only when 
some Indian goes to Temecula.
I will be glad when am through
here. At Pala I could loaf around
the store evenings and talk with
people who came in but here
there is not even one store. I 
expect to remain here two weeks
Then will go to Cahuillo some 35
miles from here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

(Pichanga) Temecula California.
Sept. 30. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting along all
right here, had a good type 
today.
This morning on my way to 
breakfast I passed the jail
a rude office made of adobe
and about 10 feet square, as I passed
the jail, some one inside called to
me to come over which I did and
I recognized an Indian I knew
at Pala he got drunk the night
before at the Fiesta said five
more were in there and wanted
me to tell the Policeman to come
and let them out, on my way
back I met one of the fellows
who was in jail said he broke
his way out said he was thirsty
I called in a brush house where
an old Indian man lived alone
Completed

he was just building a fire for
breakfast, tried to make him
understand about his sitting for
a portrait for me, so finally took
him to his nearest neighbor to
translate. I asked the other
Indian if he could talk English
he said no, I says cant you 
understand any English at all
and he replied no, a little angry.
I did not believe him and told
him to tell the old man what
I wanted of him and he did, the
old man went back and hitched
up the worst looking white plug
of a horse and the most deflated
carriage and harness I ever saw
and came and sat for me.
Am old blind Indian woman
stood outside the house, I had
gone too and had a string in
her hand which she fastened
to the house and lead her self
where she wanted to go. She was
the Mother of the man who said
Completed

(3) he could not talk English.
and she and this man and his 
wife will sit for me. I have
nearly enough subjects engaged
ahead to keep me busy two 
weeks, as long as I care to
stop here.
I have a pretty good place to eat
at the Fiesta, but the bed I 
sleep in is a foot too short.
These Indians live on their allots-
ments each Indian has about
20 acres of land but the water
is the problem, the Indian I am
stopping with has dug two wells
but they do not hold much
water not near enough for the
few families in the neighborhood
and cattle and horses.
On my return from breakfast
three Indians were still in the
jail they had kicked a hole
through the door and the
slim ones could crawl through
Completed

two of the Indians left had
stomachs too large to get through
but the one who could crawl
through asked me if he should
crawl out I told him no to
stay until the Policeman came.
Shortly after, while I was at
work the three came to my 
place they had knocked another
board off and got out, one
of the fellows had sat for me at
Pala and one of them is as
fine a type as I have seen
among the Mission Indians he lives
here and said he would sit for me
He was at Pala and I noticed.
what a fine type he was.
I have a good place to work 
in, in this store room a good 
North light by opening the door.
Your affectionate nephew.

Elbridge.
Completed

Temecula. California.
Oct. 4. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am getting along fine
here, have all the fine subjects
I want to sit for me.
The Indian family I am stopping
with have come home now as
the Fiesta is over.
There is in the family the Father
Mother a daughter some 20 years
old a son 18 another Daughter
6 years old and boy 8.
They are a very happy family,
always laughing and very
kind to me, I told them not to
put themselves out for me, but
live as they always do.
They all are as healthy as can 
be, no ailment. Their food is
very plain mostly boiled meat
with vegetables boiled with it
and boiled rice, they eat no
pastry at all and their bread
Completed

is what they call "tortia" no
baking powder in it and very
palatable and healthy.
While we eat the chickens are
under the table eating also.
I made some red drawings of an
old Indian woman 100 or over
years old, she certainly looks it,
she sat fine for me and when
she was through I made her a
present of calico enough for a
dress for her. She was born
in Temecula and remembers when
the Spanish and Americans fought.
She could tell a lot of interesting
things about the Indians, but
the trouble is, the Indians do not
like to translate very much, the old
ladys memory is very good.
I will be here 11 more days
then will go to San Jacinto some
25 miles from here.
It is very warm here during the
day but the nights are cool.
The Indian I am stopping with
Completed

(3) used to live in an adobe house
but 5 years ago they had an
earthquake here and the roof and
three walls all fell in, about
four oclock in the morning he was
in the house at the time but
did not get hurt, the house in
ruins is in the yard near his
wooden house, he says he does not
want any more adobe houses,
but then they are the most
comfortable houses here, always
cool in the hottest weather.
I have a fine old subject coming
for me tomorrow and about
the finest subject I have had
as yet coming day after tomorrow
He is a great Peon player. and
the old fellow who has charge of
the Peons games when he is on hand
sat for me. he is the umpire
of the Peon games, these games
are very interesting and well
worth seeing, they are played
Completed

mostly at night around a big
bon fire, it is a gambling game
and when ever it is played a
big crowd is around watching it.
They generally play it at the Fiestas
When am through here will send
some red drawings to you. 
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

][The FARMER HOTEL]
[San Jacinto, Cal.,] Oct 10 [190]5
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here this noon
and have just returned from the
Soboba Mission Indians, their
reservation is some three miles from
here. I am going back this evening
and will stop with the School
teacher for the Indians there on the
reservation, they have a fine place.
and I will probably be there for 
several days.
These Indians seem to be well fixed,
live in better looking houses
than the Pichanga Indians
and have plenty of water.
The School teacher seems to
think I will have trouble to get
them to sit for me, but I will
get all I want anyway.
Completed

I saw some fine baskets out there
they make. The Teacher showed me
one that he said "Ramona" made
She lives at the place I am going
to from here, "Cahuillo" 38 miles
over the mountains.
I will close now and
write you again in a few days
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
Completed

San Jacinto. California.
Oct. 12. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am nicely located here
with the teacher and his wife for
the Indians. This School is three
miles from town "San Jacinto," right
among the houses the Indians live in
Am having a harder time to get
these Indians to sit for me than
had at Pala but am getting them
all right, a good many tourists
have been here and the Indians are
a little skeptical.
These Indians have 5 acres of land
each which they raise things on.
but as a rule they all seem to 
have plenty of work picking fruit
etc for the white people.
Completed

They use to have plenty of water to
irrigate with which came from the
mountains a little ways above here
but a white man got control of
the water so the Indians do not
get any from that source.
These Indians are the Soboba branch
of the Mission Indians and are
different looking and acting from
the Mission branches at Pala
seem to be more independent and
harder to make a bargain with, one
reason I think is because they
live so near town Indians who
live among the whites are harder
for me to deal with than those
who live away from the whites.
A great deal of the "Ramona" 
story took place in this valley
and at San Jacinto.
Completed

The woman who nursed Ramona
when her husband was shot and
who figures a good deal in the story
lives today in San Jacinto and lives
in the same house she did when Ramona
was here, she is a fine old lady they
tell me and glad to have people call
on her, I may call. Helen Hunt Jackson
wrote a good deal of the story in her
house. and a half mile from where
I am, stands the old adobe school
house which was used at the time
of "Ramona" Mrs Jackson also wrote
some of her story in that school house.
I went to a livery stable at San Jacinto
to see about going to Cahuilla
from here, when get ready to go
and The livery man, an old man,
who has lived here for years told
me the original "Ramona" lives there
and for me to get a portrait of her.
Completed

He said there were two Ramona's in the
story that Mrs Jackson used two Indian
women for "Ramona" He said he knew
Mrs Jackson saw her around here and
said he knew Ramona's husband well
that the man who shot Ramona's
husband was a partner of his in
the livery business. that Ramonas husband
had his horse in the corral, and
he was intoxicated and got his partners
horse instead of his own and rode home
with it and that his partner being
a hard character and also intoxicated
at the time, when he saw his horse
gone chased after the Indian up 
the mountain and shot him.
The Hotel at Temecula is still
used as a Hotel (I stopped over
night in it) where Mrs Jackson
wrote part of her story in.
Completed

I will do my level best to get a
portrait of "Ramona"
It seems nice to sleep in a bed with
a pillow and sheets and clean food
to eat, and no fleas.
When am through here will send you
some red drawings.
The Indian who is coming to sit
for me tomorrow is a fine type
and the head man here, when
any of the Indians wish to marry
here they go to him and get his 
permission.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

San Jacinto. Calif.
Oct. 20. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am getting along
fine here, have not lost any
time so far, have got some
good subjects here.
I have such a fine place to
stop in, the nicest place have
been to yet, have a horse and
buggy at my disposal, which
I use a good deal.
I will have to go to Los Angeles
before going to Cohuilla to have
my eye glasses changed, Los 
Angeles is some 90 miles from
here I think.
These Soboba Indians make a
fine basket I have one of them.
Completed

A good many of these Indians are
away now picking and drying
fruit, they are very independent
and some of them are hard to
get to sit for me.
They all seem to have good
horses and carriages and are
very industrious, the only trouble
so many of them drink too 
much, a few months ago
an Indian was shot here by
another Indian on account of
drink and this week the
Indian was tried in Los Angeles
and sentenced to seven years in
jail.
I will be leaving in a few
days for Cohuilla some 38
miles up in the mountains
but you can address me here
Completed

as the Post Office is several 
miles away and the mail only
comes twice a week.
I will send you some red
drawings soon that I made at
Pichanga and here.
These Soboba Indians have always
lived where they are now there are
only a few of them, only 28 children
are in the school here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

San Jacinto. Calif.

Oct. 26. 05.

My dear Uncle Ed
I am sending you by
Ex Today 30 red drawings
of the Temecula, Soboba and
La Jolla branch of the Mission
Indians.
In the box there is one red
drawing for my Mother it is
wrapped up in separate news
paper the title of it is 
"Mah-ley". Wish you would
please leave it in your Office
and when some of the folks are
in they can call for it.
I have got to go to Los Angeles
to have my eye glasses changed
Completed

I have a little more work to do
here, then am going to Banning
some 18 miles from here for
Mission Indians there, called
Portiero Indians, then I go to
Cahuilla.

There has been two deaths since

I have been here among these Soboba
Indians and I have had a hard
time to get them to sit for me.
It is fortunate for me that
any of the Indians I have
painted or made portraits of
have not died they would 
surely blame it to me and
the picture, as it is they say
the Doctor was the cause of
the two deaths.
They have a regular Christian
burial as far as the burial
is concerned but the night
before the burial all the Indians
go to the home where the death
Completed

(3)
occured and dance and sing all
night and all attend the burial.
Years ago they used to cremate
their dead but the Priests
taught them to bury their dead.
They have a regular burying
ground here.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

San Jacinto. California

Oct. 28. 05.

My dear Uncle Ed
Do you still want me
to go to the Philippines? If so
I will go as soon as hear from 
you.

I can on my return, take up

my work here with these
Mission Indians. I probably
would not be gone more than
four months.
If you want me to go. I will
gladly go, as want to please you.
In case you want me to go
wish you would please send me
the letters of introduction you
spoke of and if not too
Completed

much trouble for you, to ask
Mr Simpson of the Santa Fe R.R.
to send me a pass from
San Jacinto Calif. to San Francisco.
The Santa Fe gives me passes in
exchange for pictures, they are
in debt to me now for passes.
If I go, then I would not loose
time in writing for a pass.
I have run across some
Cahuilla and La Jolla Indians
here so am getting them to sit
for me. I sent you some
La Jolla red drawings.
I received a letter from my
Father telling me of how my
Mothers brothers and sisters
remembered her on her birthday
I was exceeding glad to hear
it as it made her so happy
and me also.
I leave Monday the 30th for
Los Angeles and will return
Completed

here and finish up with these
Indians.
I wish you would please let me
know soon as you can in
regard to going to the Philippines.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. You can address me to
San Jacinto California
Riverside Co.
Completed

[Hollenbeck Hotel.]
[Los Angeles. Cal] Oct 30 [190]5
My dear Uhcle Ed
I arrived here today
I have got to have two sets
of glasses one to read by 
and one to work by.
I wrote you in regard to
going to the Philippines,
and I have been thinking 
about it since wrote you.
The fare there and back is
$335.00 good for four
months. It probably would
cost me about $80.00 
a month there, to pay for
models and living and I
believe you wanted 50 red
drawings of natives there.
Completed

In getting the natives to sit
for me I probably would
have to go inland, as I 
have to for the Indians here.
I have been wondering if it is
safe there to go inland
among those natives, and
if it would be healthy there.
I have talked with people
who have been there and they
tell me there is lots of malaria,
fever and small pox there and
one has to be careful.
I want to please you.
If you think it is better
for me to not go and
remain here and work
among these Indians as am
doing now I will do so.
I have an awful big
field here and lots of
work ahead of me and
I am much interested in
the Mission Indians here
Completed

and a good many weeks
work ahead of me yet
among them.
It would be a great
saving if I could get
transportations over there and
back.
Hoping to hear from
you soon.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. You can address me
to San Jacinto. California.
River Side Co. I return there
tomorrow.
Completed

Banning. California.
Nov. 9. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours received
I also think it is just as well to go
on with my Indian work here for some time
You must have a very complete
collection of photographs in the 5500
photographs you have of the natives of
the Philippines.
I am hard at work here, am
stopping on the reservation four
miles from Banning. I have a nice
place to get my meals with the
Teacher and his wife for the
Indians but have not got a very
nice place to work and sleep in
I am living in an old abandoned
School house, in the room is nothing
Completed

but an old stove with the stove pipe gone
several old school seats and desks
and an old table. I have a cot for a
bed, the legs on one end are broken
so I prop it up on a school bench.
The teacher is so cra[m]ped for room I
could not stop with him, but I am 
comfortably fixed.
There are three tribes of the Mission
Indians here viz Cahuilla, Seranno
and Chimevavas.
At San Jacinto I found one Cahuilla
Indian woman and she sat for me
will send her picture with the next lot.
Today a Cahuilla man sat for me
These Indians have a fine country, their
land is allotted and each family
are living on their allotments. Their
land is fenced in and they raise as
a rule lots of fruit such as
Prunes Apricots peaches etc.
Then they get plenty of work from
the whites, picking fruit drying it
Completed

etc. They seem very prosperous and
look it, seem to have fairly good
horses and wagons. They seem not to 
like to send their children to school
there are scarcely 8 Indian children in
school and I am told there are
30 children of age to go, over 12
years of age the Indian children are
not supposed to go to the day
school but are sent of to some
boarding school.
The Catholics have a large Indian boarding
school some three miles from Banning
with an attendance of 100 children
The mail does not come out here so
I generally walk to town every day for
my mail, today I thought I would
ride horse back, so told an Indian
I would give him 50 cts if he would
let me ride his horse to town and back.
Completed

which he agreed to. I asked him if his horse
was lively, would buck and try to throw me,
he said no he was gentle but a little
lazy, well I should say he was gentle
and a little lazy. he would not even
walk, so the Indian got hold of him and
pulled him and the minute he let go
the horse would stop, so I concluded to
walk to town. These Indians do not
wear a mustache and whiskers as much
as the other Mission Indians have been to.
They are more independent more business
like and are looking out for a chance
to make some money.
The house I live in the Indians use
as a Counsel house.
Think I will get some good types here.
You can send checks to Harvard
Bank as have been doing.
Will write you again in a few 
days.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

Banning. California.
Nov. 19. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I am getting along fine
here have all the Subjects I want to sit
for me and the head men of the tribe.
When I got here I was told there
were a lot of Cahuillas here but there
are very few, not enough for me to
get types of, so I will go to the
Cahuilla country a rather desolate place.
The principal Indians here are the
Seranno. They are a distinct tribe
by themselves have their own language
and are very thrifty and hard
workers, nearly all of them speak English.
The Chief of the tribe sat for me
yesterday and comes again tomorrow
after him his wife comes.
I probably will leave here in a
week am going to Coachella some
30 miles from here in the desert on
the Southern Pacific R.R. which is
only a few miles from the Salton
Sea. Those Indians are called The
Desert Indians. The Agent went their
Completed

this week, to see about the Salton sea
water that is getting near them. They are
afraid they will have to move.
These Seranno Indians seem to be the
most prosperous and best educated of
any tribe I have visited, one Indian girl
who sat for me lives near by she has
bought herself a piano and plays very
nicely. She was working in Banning
and her cousins wife died and left
three children so she gave up her work
and has come out here to keep house for
her cousin and be a Mother to the three
Indian children. All thee Indians live in wooden
houses some of them good comfortable
houses with several rooms, a few years
ago they lived in adobe houses but they
had a severe earthquake here a few years
ago and the adobe houses fell in and
several Indians were killed. An Indian
I lived with at Pichanga he was sleeping
in an adobe house the time of the earthquake,
his house fell in on him but he escaped
uninjured and built him a wooden house.
I will write you again soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. You can address me to 
Coachella. California.
Completed

Banning California.
Nov. 24. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I will send you 24 red
drawings to day by W. F. Ex.
charges prepaid.
Among the red drawings I send you
are the Seranno, Cahuilla, Soboba
and San Ignacio. I ran across one
San Ignacio Indian woman at
Soboba and at Soboba I found
one or two Cahuilla and also two
Cahuilla here one lives here and the other
came here to work.
The Seranno's are the best type I have
found so far among the Mission
Indians There are very few of them
left not more than 40.
They have their own distinct
language and are in size very
large and powerfully built.
I will do some more work yet
here then I leave for the desert
Completed

where a branch of the Mission Indians
live, am told they are called the
Desert Indians and The Chimevavas
are there also.
You can address me to Coachella.
California.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

Coachella. California.
Dec. 2. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here last night and have
a nice clean room clean bed to sleep in
and a clean place to eat and have an
Indian coming at noon to sit for me.
I had good luck at Banning a
San Ignacio Indian came there to visit
and he sat for me they are very scarce
only a few of them left. They have their own
distinct language.
This place is 76 feet below sea level
and the Salton Sea is but 13 miles from
here rising they tell me all the time
but they say here it has to rise 200
feet before it can touch this place.
Some of the Indians live half a mile from
here and some four miles from here
I went out to the nearest ones
this morning. They live in crude
brush houses plenty of air almost an
out door life their house practically
is four poles and merely a roof of
brush but I noticed some wooden
houses they live in They seem to have
Completed

fine rich land and irrigated and they work.
They make fine baskets and are rather
cheap.
The climate is fine here now much warmer
than at Banning as it is nearly some
3000 feet lower in altitude.
I got well acquainted with the Indians
at Banning they are very progressive
but the trouble is they do not have
enough water to irrigate with at one
time they did and they planted a lot
of fruit trees grapes etc but the water
got less so had to give up that mode
of making a living and there are a
few deserted houses there some went to
the different towns to work some of them
who can get more water work on their
farms still. They were very particular about
the old rickety house I worked in, hardly 
as good as a barn. I myself set the
price on what rent I should pay for such
a place there were 11 window panes
broken out over half of one whole window
was gone not a chair in the place
and a stove with the stove pipe gone
a very dirty floor could'nt lock the
door, no key and I had to buy
cloth to cover the four windows
Completed

so I thought $1.00 a week was plenty for
such a deserted house. They did'nt know
about it they held a meeting and came
to the conclusion that I ought to have asked
them what rent they wanted for such a place by
the week, they said if I had done that the
chances are they would not charge me a
cent as they knew it was not much of
a place, but finally the Captain and
Policeman of the Indians called on me one
day and said $1.00 a week was all right
and enough. Before I moved into the
house I saw the Missionary who holds
services there in a church every Sunday and he had
told me he saw the head one of the
Indians and that I could work and
sleep there. The Captain and his wife
sat for me the Policeman would'nt sit
at first I told him I would have to rope him and
tie him to the chair, he said he would sit
if I paid him double what I did for
the others which I would not do but
the last few days I was there he came
around and wanted to sit but I had
others engaged so didnt have him.
I probably will be here some two
weeks it depends on the Indians
Will write you again in a few days.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

Coachella. Calif.
Dec. 12. 05.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I am getting along all
right here and like it here
very much. The low altitude
76 feet below sea level seems
to agree with me.
I had quite a time to get
the Chimavava Indians to
sit for me There are but
very few of them left here
hardly 15, I believe only 4
men left. They are different
from the Cahuilla Indians
different type and very
superstitious, some of them
would not sit for a portrait
for anything and talked
to those that did or that
promised to come but I
got a man and woman
and hope to get some more
before I leave here.
They live near the Cahuillo's
but all by them selves
Completed

I do not believe they are
the Mission Indians as they
claim they came here from
Colorado. They live in
rudely constructed houses
made of brush and all seem
to be very industrious

after he had sat some fifteen
minutes he became restless and
thought I ought to be through.
I explained to him how long it
took me, but in a half hour he
got mad said it took too long
was too hard work and he wanted
to quit but I would not let him
finally he said I was "no good"

how long it took to make a picture
and that I was no good.

I knew if he did that it would
interfere a good deal with my work
here, so I lost my temper with him

and I gave him a good talking

if he carried out his threat that
I would go to the Depot Agent

Completed

They are really works of Art.
A Mr Cahn here whom I have
met has a big collection of
baskets on hand mostly Washoes
and Pah Utes, he showed them to 
me.
You probably have heard of that
Washoe squaw named "Dah-so-lee
her white name is "Luisa Karsar"
She is considered the finest basket
maker of an Indian in the World
her name and baskets have been
illustrated in several Magazines
and newspapers the Smithsonian
has her baskets illustrated in a 
book they have published.
Mr Cahn says she makes but one
basket a year and he gets them
all, She lives at his house. She
now is some 70 years old. He showed
me her baskets, he has but a few
on hand. some of her baskets costs
$1500.00 I enclose to you a cut of
three of her baskets I saw no's
24 and 26 which My Cahn has.
These Indians live in and
around Carson City in crude
Completed

(3) wooden houses. They do odd
jobs around town. From the out
look I will have good success
with them in getting them to sit
for me.
I am stopping at the Hotel
here and have good meals
and a good place to work.
What Indians I have seen
here so far have mostly a
smooth face they are fine
types, better than the Mission
Indians, they are not a very
large people in statue most
of them speak English.
I will write you again soon.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. As soon as I am through
with Nevada I will return to
California and work among
the Northern Indians in California.
Completed

Carson City. Nevada.
Mch 29th.06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I will send you today
by W. F. Ex Co 32 red drawings
10 of them are Pah Utes I did a
lot of work here and worked
hard.
I did not get as many Pah Utes
here as wanted as there are very
few Pah Utes here so I will go
to Reno. Nevada. today and
I will find a lot of Pah Utes there.
I will stop at Reno but a few
days, then I am going to Elko.
Nevada for the Shoshonie Indians.
I had a hard time to get these
Indians to tell me their Indian
names The white people here told
me that the Indians here never
tell their Indian names but I
succeeded in getting all but
some three or four to give me their
Completed

Indian name They would always tell
me their white name and would say
they had no Indian name. Those that
I could not get their Indian name
declared up and down they never had an
Indian name. so I would invite other
Indians to see the picture but they would
always say that is so and so and
give the white name and they told
me those Indians had no Indian name.
As far as I can learn these Indians
here do not do any farm work I
dont believe they have any land except
what their rude houses occupy
and some of their houses are about
the most wretched I ever saw, still
these Indians seem to get along all
right They all seem to be doing
some kind of work for the white people.
The Pah Ute is a better type than the
Washoe the Washoe is inclined
to be fat and fleshy.
There are not many tribes of
Completed

(3) Indians in Nevada, so far I have
only learned of three different tribes
the Washoe Pah-Ute and Shoshonie.
There are several different branches of the
Pah-Ute but they live mostly in Utah.
I expect to return to California from
Elko and go with the Northern California
Indians.
You can address me to
Elko. Nevada.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. The papers here gave me
some complimentary notices.
Completed

Reno. Navada
Mch.30. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed
I arrived here last
night and am nicely located
here.
I got to work this morning
on a Pah-Ute Indian, there are
plenty of Pah Ute's here but they
are so superstitious. I had a
time with this Indian today to
get him to sit for me He was
afraid he was going to die
but I finally convinced him he would
live all right, but when I had
made one portrait of him he wanted
to quit & I had an awful time
to get him to sit for another
picture. He felt better when he left
and said he would get his wife
to sit for me and other 
Pah-Utes.
These Pah Utes have a reservation
Completed

several miles from here, but there
are quite a number of them that
live around this town enough
for me to get all the good types
I want.
As far as I can learn there are
only the Pah Utes, Washoe and
Shoshone Indians in Nevada.
I will only remain here about a week
as I got some portraits of
Pah Utes in Carson City then
I will go to Elko Nevada
which is some 300 miles East
of here on Southern Pacific
Railroad for the Shoshone
Indians.
These Indians here work at
odd jobs around town they are
fine types.
The University here wants one
of my portraits to publish in
a Magazine that the University
publishes here.
Completed

(3) I am sure you will like the
red drawings I sent you yesterday
of the Washoe and Pah Ute
Indians they are strong types
quite different from the Mission
Indians in Southern California.
The Indian who sat for me today
was just in with his wife
and she has promised to come
tomorrow.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
P.S. Address me to
Elko. Nevada.
Completed

Wadsworth. Nevada.
April. 5. 06.
My dear Uncle Ed.
I made six red drawings
at Reno Nev. of Pah Ute Indians
There were not enough old people
there to suit me so I came here
and I have a lot of fine subjects
to choose from and some noted
Indians among them, an old
Pah Ute Indian sat for me today
who has been in fights against
the Soldiers, his Father was a scout
for Fremont.
The next day after I arrived here
I drove out to the Pah Ute
reservation 18 miles from here but
The Agent there for the Indians told
me that Wadsworth was a better
place for me, more old people
here and better types so I came here.
The Pah Ute have a fine Agency
good land, the Truckee River
Completed

runs through their reservation and
they have a fine irrigating ditch so
that they can irrigate their land
and I saw the Indians plowing
and getting ready to plant
The Pyramid Lakes is four miles
from the Agency these lakes are
some 60 miles long and very
fine fishing quite a number of
the Pah Ute Indians live near the
Lakes and catch fine trout and
sell them to people living in
near by towns and do well.
Pyramid Lakes are very beautiful
sourounded with mountains
There are Several gold, silver and
copper mines in the mountains
close by to the Pah-Ute reservation
Nearly all these Indians speak
fairly good English and they are
very sociable and agreeable and
easy to handle when treated right.
The Pah-Utes are scattered around
in several places in Nevada
I made some portraits of them in
Completed

(3) Carson City, Reno and now here
I will finish up with them here then
I go to Elko Nevada for the Shoshone
Indians.
The Pah Utes here live in crude
wooden houses and one family
lives in a house made of old
rags pieces of casket tin and
iron etc a most dilapidated
looking house.
One old blind Pah Ute man makes 
fish nets of bark, they are a very
good net. He is a fine type
I will try and get the old fellow
to sit for me.
This Town a few months ago
was on the main line of the
Southern Pacific R.R. it was the
end of a division had it's shops
here and employed a few hundred
men but the division was changed
to another place the shops moved
the main line moved a mile
away a great many of the
houses were also moved away
Completed

leaving but a few white people
here when at one time the population
was some 2000 and about the
time the railroad moved a fire
burned up a good many houses
and now it is the most
desolate and sad looking town
I have been to. it is amusing and
also sad to hear the hard luck
stories the few remaining sad
looking people have to relate
They say even the fine steel
bridge was moved away so
now a stub train runs here
with but one baggage car
and passenger coach combined
in one. The few sad looking
people here hang on to the place
hoping that something will turn
up to improve the town. I asked
how do these people make a living
here, they dont know.
The Hotel I stop at is a rather
large Hotel with some 40 rooms
but at present I am the sole and
Completed

(5) only guest. The dining room is
closed so I get my meals of a
jolly happy looking Chinaman.
I asked him what kept him here,
he said he hung on hoping that
a stamp mill might locate
here which is being talked of.
The place reminds me of a deserted
burying ground people go around
sad looking and only glad to
tell you what the place once was.
Yesterday a man said to me, he
says why man I have seen
300 people eating in the Dining
room of the Hotel business was
good this was the liveliest place
between San Francisco and Ogden.
The Truckee irrigating ditch
that the Government has built
costing many million of dollars
runs with in a mile of here
I walked out to it this afternoon.
The main ditch is finished and
water running in it and they 
are at work now upon small
Completed

ditches to irrigate the land on each
side of the main ditch one ditch
is to irrigate land adjoining
Wadsworth which will help this
place, which tends to bring a
smile in the faces of some of these
sad looking people.
The many trains there run by
only a mile from here, the whistle
from the locomotives can be heard
plainly from here, which of course
tends to remind these people here
of past prosperous times.
The Indians around here seem to
be happy, the Indian women dig
around where the locomotives once
stood for coal and sell it for
50 cts a sack.
The land lord who owns this
Hotel hangs in here, he spends
a good share of his time sitting
in the Office playing solitaire
I have plenty of room, have a
choice of rooms to sleep in and
I use the big parlor for a Studio
Completed

(7) and am not bothered at all
with guests walking in on me.
At first the Land lord objected
to my using the parlor for a Studio.
Well he says you can use it, as
there is not much travel this
way now.
You can address me to
Elko. Nevada.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
